title: AIG Marks Major Progress
sub_head: Investors already know that a lot of capital return is likely coming, but the core property-and-casualty business is doing quite well, too
body:
American International Group is looking like more than just a breakup story.
Following moves to sell a stake in its life-and-retirement business to Blackstone Group ahead of a listing, plus an accompanying sale of affordable-housing assets, AIG looks poised to add several billion dollars to its cash pile. It already has announced an increase of its share buyback authorization to $6 billion.
Shareholders might welcome lots of extra cash in their pockets after years of patience with the insurance behemoth. But AIG isn’t just a capital-return story right now—at least based on these most recent quarterly results.
In fact, now also looks to be a good time to have the capital to fund a bigger book of core property-and-casualty business. Premiums and new business are rising fast, and underwriting results are strong, particularly in commercial insurance. That dynamic suggests the potential to grow in a way that doesn’t just mean buying more risk to gain market share.
Global commercial net premiums written were up 13% in the second quarter from a year earlier, adjusted for the effects of foreign-currency translation, due to rate increases and new business. The underlying accident-year combined ratio for commercial insurance fell by some 5 points to 89.3%, which AIG said was the best performance in 15 years. This core measure falls as losses and expenses become a smaller percentage of premium collected, and it excludes the effect of catastrophes and adjustments for losses in prior years.
